name: Castelo de Sao Jorge (St. George's Castle)
tagline: Lisbon's historic hilltop fortress with panoramic city views

description.short: Perched on Lisbon's highest hill, this 11th-century Moorish castle offers spectacular 360-degree views over the city and Tagus River. Explore medieval battlements, archaeological ruins, and royal palace remains while peacocks roam the grounds.
description.full: Castelo de Sao Jorge dominates Lisbon's skyline from atop the city's highest hill in the historic Alfama district. Originally built by the Moors in the mid-11th century, this imposing fortress became the residence of Portuguese kings after Christian conquest in 1147 and remained the royal palace until the 16th century. The castle complex encompasses 11 towers connected by massive walls, offering visitors the chance to walk the battlements and enjoy breathtaking panoramic views over Lisbon's terracotta rooftops, the Tagus River estuary, and the 25 de Abril Bridge. Within the fortified citadel, visitors can explore the Museum Centre showcasing artifacts from Phoenician, Roman, Moorish, and Medieval periods discovered during archaeological excavations. The Camera Obscura provides a unique 360-degree real-time view of the city below, while the archaeological site reveals layers of Lisbon's 2,500-year history. The castle gardens are home to a flock of peacocks and other birds, adding to the magical atmosphere. Though damaged by the 1755 earthquake and later used as barracks and prison, extensive 20th-century restoration returned the castle to its medieval glory. Today it stands as Lisbon's most visited monument and a powerful symbol of Portuguese resilience and history.
description.history: The hilltop was first fortified by indigenous Iberians, then occupied by Romans, Visigoths, and finally the Moors who built the first substantial castle in the mid-11th century as part of Lisbon's Moorish defenses. In 1147, during the Second Crusade, King Afonso Henriques captured Lisbon from the Moors after a three-month siege, with crucial help from Northern European crusaders. The castle became the royal palace and seat of power for Portuguese kings. King Dinis I rebuilt parts of the castle in the early 14th century, and King Manuel I further expanded it in the 16th century before moving the royal residence to the new Ribeira Palace near the river. After the 1755 earthquake severely damaged the castle, it was converted into military barracks and later a prison. The castle fell into disrepair until major restoration began in the 1940s under Estado Novo regime. Extensive archaeological excavations from 1990s onward uncovered multiple layers of occupation spanning 2,500 years. Today it is managed by EGEAC and is Lisbon's most iconic landmark.
description.significance: Castelo de Sao Jorge represents the historical and political heart of Lisbon, serving as the city's main defensive fortification for nearly a millennium. The 1147 Christian conquest of the castle marked a turning point in the Reconquista and the birth of Portugal as an independent kingdom. As the royal residence for three centuries, it witnessed crucial moments in Portuguese history, including royal ceremonies, political decisions, and the Age of Discoveries planning. The castle's survival through earthquakes, wars, and centuries of change symbolizes Lisbon's resilience. Its commanding position and iconic silhouette make it the most recognizable symbol of the city, appearing on countless postcards and photographs.

address.street: Rua de Santa Cruz do Castelo

directions.general: Located on the highest hill in central Lisbon, in the historic Castelo neighborhood above Alfama district
directions.fromCruisePort: 3.5km from Santa Apolonia cruise port - take bus 737 direct to castle entrance (20 minutes), or taxi/Uber (10-15 minutes). Tram 28E from port area possible but crowded. Walking uphill from port: 45 minutes steep climb.
directions.publicTransport: Bus 737 from Praca da Figueira to Castelo stop at entrance. Tram 28E stops nearby but requires uphill walk. Buses 734 and 35E also serve the area. From Baixa, steep 15-20 minute uphill walk.
directions.parking: Limited paid parking near castle entrance on Rua de Santa Cruz do Castelo. Not recommended to drive - narrow medieval streets.

seasonal.notes: Wall-walks and towers close at 17:30 for safety
Wall-walks and towers may close between 18:00-21:00 depending on daylight

admissionPrices.notes: Children under 10 free. Youth 10-17 and students with ID. Seniors 65+. Lisbon residents free on Sundays and public holidays until 14:00. Book online for guaranteed entry time.

visitingInformation.bestTimeToVisit: Early morning at opening (9am) for fewer crowds and best light for photos. Late afternoon (after 5pm) for sunset views. Avoid midday heat in summer.
visitingInformation.adviceForVisitors: Wear comfortable walking shoes - lots of stairs and uneven stone surfaces. Bring water, especially in summer. Camera essential for panoramic views. Arrive early or late for fewer crowds. Camera Obscura tours included in ticket - check schedule at entrance. Free guided tours available daily. Allow 1.5-2 hours minimum. Peacocks roam freely - don't feed them. Some areas have steep drops - supervise children closely.

cruisePassengerInfo.timeNeededFromPort: 2.5-3 hours minimum (includes travel, visit, and exploration)
cruisePassengerInfo.accessibility: Good - direct bus 737 from city center, or short taxi ride from port. Castle has some steep stairs but main viewpoints accessible.
